quiz.instruction:
Choose

NO MORE THAN TWO WORDS AND/OR A NUMBER

from the passage for each answer.
Do the following statements agree with the information given in passage?

Reading Passage 2 has seven paragraphs, A–G.

Which paragraph contains the following information?

Write the correct letter, A–G, in boxes 14–18 on your answer sheet.

matchings.question: bad outcomes for a forest when people focus only on its financial reward
matchings.explain: Paragraph B discusses how focusing only on high-quality timber (financial reward) through 'high-grading' has left a legacy of low-use wood, which decreases forest health.

matchings.question: reference to the aspects of any tree that contribute to its worth
matchings.explain: Paragraph A begins by explaining that a tree's value depends on several factors including species, size, form, condition, etc.

matchings.question: mention of the potential use of wood to help run vehicles
matchings.explain: Paragraph C states: "Wood can also be gasified for electrical generation and can even be made into liquid fuels like ethanol and gasoline for lorries and cars."

matchings.question: examples of insects that attack trees
matchings.explain: Paragraph E lists pests and pathogens including "hemlock wooly adelgid, Asian longhorned beetle, emerald ash borer, and gypsy moth".

matchings.question: an alternative name for trees that produce low-use wood
matchings.explain: Paragraph B says: "Some people even call these 'junk trees'..." referring to trees that produce low-use wood.

quiz.title: IELTS Reading Test 1 - Passage 2: Forest management in Pennsylvania, USA
quiz.instruction:
Look at the following purposes (Questions 19–21) and the list of timber cuts below.

Match each purpose with the correct timber cut, A, B or C.

Write the correct letter, A, B or C, in boxes 19–21 on your answer sheet.

matchings.question: to remove trees that are diseased
matchings.explain: Paragraph E describes Salvage Cuts: "These types of cut reduce the number of sick trees and seek to manage the future spread of a pest problem."

matchings.question: to generate income across a number of years
matchings.explain: Paragraph F states about Shelterwood Cut: "There are two harvests and the money that comes in is spread out over a decade or more."

matchings.question: to create a forest whose trees are close in age
matchings.explain: Paragraph F says: "It leaves a young forest where all trees are at a similar point in their growth."

quiz.title: IELTS Reading Test 1 - Passage 2: Forest management in Pennsylvania, USA
quiz.instruction:
Choose

ONE WORD ONLY

from the passage for each answer.

questions.question: Some dead wood is removed to avoid the possibility of ……….
questions.explain: Paragraph G states: "Thinnings and dense and dead wood removal for fire prevention..." So the answer is 'fire'.

questions.question: The ………. from the tops of cut trees can help improve soil quality.
questions.explain: Paragraph G says: "The tops of trees that have been cut down should be left on the site so that their nutrients cycle back into the soil."

questions.question: Some damaged trees should be left, as their ………. provide habitats for a range of creatures.
questions.explain: Paragraph G mentions: "trees with many cavities are extremely important habitats for insect predators..."

questions.question: Some trees that are small, such as ………., are a source of food for animals and insects.
questions.explain: Paragraph G gives the example: "many species like hawthorn provide food for wildlife."

questions.question: Any trees that are ………. should be left to grow, as they add to the variety of species in the forest.
questions.explain: Paragraph G states: "Finally, rare species of trees in a forest should also stay behind as they add to its structural diversity."

quiz.title: IELTS Reading Test 1 - Passage 3: Conquering Earth's space junk problem
quiz.instruction:
Which section contains the following information?

Write the correct letter, A–F, in boxes 27–31 on your answer sheet.

matchings.question: a reference to the cooperation that takes place to try and minimise risk
matchings.explain: Paragraph C discusses how companies, governments, and other players are collaborating to avoid space debris threats, and mentions the Inter-Agency Space Debris Coordination Committee.

matchings.question: an explanation of a person's aims
matchings.explain: Paragraph F ends with Jah describing himself as a space environmentalist and his aim to make space safe and useful for future generations.

matchings.question: a description of a major collision that occurred in space
matchings.explain: Paragraph A describes the collision between a US Iridium satellite and a Russian Cosmos-2251 satellite.

matchings.question: a comparison between tracking objects in space and the efficiency of a transportation system
matchings.explain: Paragraph E compares space traffic management to managing traffic on roads or in the air, specifically mentioning air traffic control.

matchings.question: a reference to efforts to classify space junk
matchings.explain: Paragraph B mentions researchers developing taxonomies of space debris, measuring properties like shape and size.

quiz.title: IELTS Reading Test 1 - Passage 3: Conquering Earth's space junk problem
quiz.instruction:
Choose

ONE WORD ONLY

from the passage for each answer.

questions.question: The committee gives advice on how the 32 ...... of space can be achieved.
questions.explain: Paragraph C states: "International groups such as the Inter-Agency Space Debris Coordination Committee have developed guidelines on space sustainability."

questions.question: The committee advises that when satellites are no longer active, any unused 33 ...... or pressurised material that could cause explosions should be removed.
questions.explain: Paragraph C says: "Those include inactivating satellites at the end of their useful life by venting pressurised materials or leftover fuel that might lead to explosions."

questions.question: any unused fuel or pressurised material that could cause 34 ...... should be removed.
questions.explain: Same as above: "leftover fuel that might lead to explosions." The word 'explosions' is directly mentioned.

questions.question: Holger Krag points out that the operators that become 35 ...... are unlikely to prioritise removing their satellites from space.
questions.explain: Paragraph C quotes Holger Krag: "What happens to those that fail or go bankrupt? They are probably not going to spend money to remove their satellites."

quiz.title: IELTS Reading Test 1 - Passage 3: Conquering Earth's space junk problem
quiz.instruction:
Look at the following statements (Questions 36–40) and the list of people below.

Match each statement with the correct person, A, B, C or D.

Write the correct letter, A, B, C or D, in boxes 36–40 on your answer sheet.

matchings.question: Knowing the exact location of space junk would help prevent any possible danger.
matchings.explain: Marlon Sorge says in paragraph D: "If you knew precisely where everything was, you would almost never have a problem."

matchings.question: Space should be available to everyone and should be preserved for the future.
matchings.explain: Moriba Jah states in paragraph F: "I want to make space a place that is safe to operate, that is free and useful for generations to come."

matchings.question: A recommendation regarding satellites is widely ignored.
matchings.explain: Holger Krag says in paragraph C: "But so far, only about half of all missions have abided by this 25-year goal..." referring to the guideline about deorbiting satellites.

matchings.question: There is conflicting information about where some satellites are in space.
matchings.explain: Moriba Jah illustrates in paragraph F that for a Russian rocket body, the US and Russian sources list two different orbits, showing conflicting information.

matchings.question: There is a risk we will not be able to undo the damage that occurs in space.
matchings.explain: Carolin Frueh warns in paragraph B: "If we go on like this, we will reach a point of no return."
